raw_text:
Millions buy MP3 players in US
 
 One in 10 adult Americans - equivalent to 22 million people - owns an MP3 player, according to a survey.
 
 A study by the Pew Internet and American Life Project found that MP3 players are the gadget of choice among affluent young Americans. The survey did not interview teenagers but it is likely that millions of under-18s also have MP3 players. The American love affair with digital music players has been made possible as more and more homes get broadband.
 
 Of the 22 million Americans who own MP3 players, 59% are men compared to 41% of women. Those on high income - judged to be $75,000 (£39,000) or above - are four times more likely to have players than those earning less than $30, 000 ( £15,000). Broadband access plays a big part in ownership too. Almost a quarter of those with broadband at home have players, compared to 9% of those who have dial-up access. MP3 players are still the gadget of choice for younger adults. Almost one in five US citizens aged under 30 have one. This compares to 14% of those aged 30-39 and 14% of those aged 40-48. The influence of children also plays a part. Sixteen percent of parents living with children under 18 have digital players compared to 9% of those who don't. The ease of use and growth of music available on the net are the main factors for the upsurge in ownership, the survey found. People are beginning to use them as instruments of social activity - sharing songs and taking part in podcasting - the survey found. "IPods and MP3 players are becoming a mainstream technology for consumers" said Lee Rainie, director of the Pew Internet and American Life Project. "More growth in the market is inevitable as new devices become available, as new players enter the market, and as new social uses for iPods/MP3 players become popular," he added.
llama3.2:1b: Millions of Americans own MP3 players, with one in 10 adult Americans owning one.
The majority are men (59%), while women (41%) have lower ownership rates.
Those on higher incomes are more likely to own an MP3 player than those earning less than $30,000.
A significant portion of households with broadband internet access also own an MP3 player.
llama3.2:3b: 22 million Americans own MP3 players, with 59% male, 41% female, and 16% of parents owning them due to children's influence.
The survey found that broadband access plays a significant role in ownership, with almost a quarter of those with broadband at home having players.
Ease of use and the growth of music available online are main factors, as well as people using them for social activity like sharing songs and podcasting.
gemma2:2b: Affluent young adults are most likely to own them.
Broadband access significantly increases MP3 player ownership.
Almost one in five US citizens under 30 own MP3 players.
The main factors for increased ownership include ease of use, digital music availability, and social applications like podcasting.
qwen2.5:0.5b: MP3 players are increasingly popular among US adults, with 59% of those owning them being men compared to 41% of women.
They are more likely to own a player than those earning less than $30, 000 ( £15, 000).
Broadband access is also a factor in who owns an MP3 player.
Nearly one in five US citizens under 30 have one, compared to 14% of those aged 30-39 and 14% of those aged 40-48.
"IPodsandMP3playersismakingamainstreamtechnologyforconsumers" said Lee Rainie, director of the Pew Internet and American Life Project.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Millions of Americans own MP3 players, particularly affluent young adults and those with broadband access, influenced by music availability online and social networking use.
qwen2.5:3b: Millions of Americans own MP3 players with 22 million adults owning them, predominantly young affluent men.
Higher income (>$75,000) and broadband access are key factors.
Younger ages (under 30) have the highest ownership rate at 19%.
Broadband users are more likely to own one (24%) compared to dial-up users (9%).
The main drivers include ease of use, increased music availability online, and social activities like sharing songs and podcasting.
Increasing market growth is expected as new devices enter the market.
opencoder:1.5b: The text highlights a rise in the popularity of MP3 players among the millennial demographic.
Broadband access has been an instrumental factor in owning these gadgets, with 59% of users being male compared to 41% females.
The demographic includes users aged under 30 who are likely to have players due to the ease of use and growth in music available online.
It's also significant that more and more homes get broadband connectivity, even for affluent users.
smollm:1.7b: The summary should preserve key ideas and details from the original text while omitting unnecessary information.

Here's how you can do it:

1.

Identify the main points of the original text: The text mentions millions buying MP3 players, a study finding that 22% of Americans own one, and a survey showing that 59% of those who own MP3 players are men.

Determine what information is essential to understanding the topic: In this case, we need to focus on the key points related to the popularity of MP3 players among affluent young adults, as well as the role of broadband access and social media in their adoption.
Omit unnecessary details: The text does not provide specific numbers or statistics about the demographics of those who own MP3 players.
It also doesn't discuss the impact of technology on society, such as the rise of online music streaming services like Spotify.
Use clear and concise language to convey the main ideas: Instead of using technical jargon or complex terminology, we can use simple language to summarize the key points from the original text.
For example, "Millions buy MP3 players in US" instead of "A study by the Pew Internet and American Life Project found that 22% of Americans own an MP3 player."

Ensure the summary is free of bias or opinion: The summary should present a neutral and objective summary of the main points from the original text, without expressing any personal opinions or biases.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Millions purchase MP3 players in the U.S., with one out of every ten adult Americans owning an MP3 player—equivalent to 22 million people.
A survey found that among affluent young Americans, MP3 players are their favorite gadgets.
Broadband access is a key factor driving ownership growth, as owners four times more likely have players than those without dial-up access.
Men (59%) and women (41%) own MP3 players in the U.S., with higher rates for upper-income earners (four times more likely).
Ownership trends show 1 in five US citizens under age 30 owning an MP3 player, rising to 14% in the 30-39 age bracket and another 14% in the 40-48 range.
The influence of children is evident—parents living with kids under 18 own players at a higher rate (16%) compared to those without.
The rise in music availability, influenced by the internet, has made sharing songs and participating in podcasts increasingly popular.
Lee Rainie from Pew's study highlights that MP3 players are becoming mainstream technology for consumers, noting ongoing growth as new devices emerge.
tinyllama:1.1b: According to a survey, millions of Americans own MP3 players, with one in 10 adults - equivalent to 22 million people - owning an MP3 player.
The survey found that among affluent young Americans who have broadband access, the likelihood of owning a digital music player is four times higher than for those earning less than $30,000 per year.
Broadband usage plays a significant role in ownership, with almost half of those with high-income homes having MP3 players compared to only 9% of those with low-income access.
The growth of music available on the internet as an instrument of social activity is also becoming mainstream for consumers, with IPods and MP3 players becoming a major part of their lives.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Millions of Americans have purchased MP3 players in recent years, making it a popular choice among affluent young adults.
In fact, one in 10 US citizens owns an MP3 player compared to 22 million people who do not own such devices.

The Pew Internet and American Life Project conducted a study of over 5,000 households in the United States and discovered that a significant portion of these young adults prefer digital music over traditional formats like vinyl records or cassettes.
The ease of use and growth of music available on the internet have contributed to this preference among consumers.

The survey also found that more than a quarter of people under 30 own MP3 players, compared to less than a third of those aged 30-39 and only around one in five individuals aged 40-48 own these devices.
Additionally, the ease of use and growth of music available on the internet are the primary factors for this surge in ownership among younger adults.
phi:2.7b: According to a survey by Pew Internet and American Life Project, 22 million Americans own MP3 players.
The study found that affluent young adults are the most likely to have these devices, with 59% of male owners earning $75,000 or more.
Broadband access also plays a significant role in ownership, as almost one-fourth of those with broadband at home have an MP3 player compared to only 9% of those with dial-up access.
The ease of use and availability of music online are the main factors for this surge in popularity.
However, younger adults are still more likely to own these devices than older adults, with 16% of those under 30 having one versus 14% of those aged 40-48.
Children also play a role, as 16% of parents living with children under 18 have MP3 players compared to only 9% of those without children.
The survey concludes that iPods and MP3 players are becoming more mainstream as new devices become available and social uses for them become popular.
orca-mini:3b: The US has a significant number of people who own MP3 players, with 22 million Americans owning them.
This is equivalent to 1 in 10 adult Americans, making it a mainstream technology for consumers.
Affluent young Americans are particularly interested in MP3 players, with 59% of those earning $75,000 or more owning them compared to only 9% of those earning less than $30,000.
Digital music players have become a part of social activity, with children also participating in podcasting and sharing songs with others.
The ease of use and availability of music on the internet are two main factors contributing to the growth of MP3 player ownership.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A survey by the Pew Internet and American Life Project found that 22 million Americans own an MP3 player, with one in 10 adults owning one, mainly among affluent young Americans.
The increase in ownership is due to factors such as broadband access and children using them for social activities like podcasting.
As new devices emerge and popular uses become widespread, it's expected that the market will grow further.
chatgpt-4o-latest: One in 10 adult Americans, or 22 million people, own an MP3 player, with ownership highest among affluent young adults.

A study by the Pew Internet and American Life Project found that men are more likely to own MP3 players than women, and high-income individuals are four times more likely to have one than lower-income earners.
Broadband access significantly influences ownership, with nearly a quarter of broadband users owning a player.
Younger adults, particularly those under 30, are the primary users, and parents with children under 18 are more likely to own one.
The rise in MP3 player ownership is driven by ease of use, increased online music availability, and social activities like song sharing and podcasting.
The study predicts continued market growth as new devices and social uses emerge.

Affluent young Americans prefer these gadgets.

Among those with broadband access, those on high income are four times more likely than those earning less than $50,0..

granite3.1-dense:2b: 22 million Americans own MP3 players, with a significant majority being affluent males (59%) and high-income individuals (41% of women).
Broadband access facilitates ownership; 26% of broadband users have MP3 players, compared to 9% with dial-up.
Younger adults under 30 are more likely to own these devices (40%), while older groups show lower adoption rates.
Parents with children under 18 have the highest proportion (16%) of digital music player owners.
The popularity of MP3 players is driven by their ease of use, growing online music selection, and emerging social uses like sharing songs and podcasting.
Lee Rainie, director of the Pew Internet and American Life Project, predicts further market growth due to new devices and social applications.
